Parts of speech

There are three important types of word in the German language 1. the noun= for objects, people, abstract concepts 2. the verb= for activities, processes in the broadest sense 3. the adjective= for characteristics Other kinds of words complete the sentences. The noun is written with a capital letter at the beginning. It is thus easy to recognise. Nouns and adjectives are modified or declined in sentences = the declension. The verb is the most difficult word because it can be very strongly modified. It is conjugated = the conjugation. The conjugated verb is know as the finites Verb, the unconjugated verb is the Infinitiv. We will begin with short sentences, which contain all three word types. We will especially observe the verb.

Personal names

People have one or more first names and a family name. Everyone is asked for these when a form must be filled out. The finite verb in interrogative sentences and in answering clauses

Please pay attention to the position of the finite, conjugated verb in interrogative sentences and answering clauses. The rule is: the finite verb stands in the 2nd position in the sentence. This is true for questions (Fragen) with interrogatives and for answers (Antworten), when the answers are simple answering clauses. For questions without an interrogative the finite verb stands at the beginning of the sentence. Questions without an interrogative are decision questions. In principle one can only answer with Ja or Nein. Other positions of the finite verb will be dealt with later.

Haben and sein can also function as dependent, auxiliary verbs; this means they help build some particular tense forms of a verb, for example the past tense/present perfect. The football match / Das Fußballspiel

The football match has a special vocabulary. There are players (Spieler), also known as football players (Fußballspieler). They want to kick the ball (Ball) or the football (Fußball) into the goal (Tor), of course into the opponent’s goal (das gegnerische Tor). The goalkeeper(Torhüter or Torwart) stands in the goal. In front of the goal is the penalty area (Strafraum). Then there is the referee (Schiedsrichter), who blows the whistle, and the linesmen (Linienrichter) who raise their flags, if certain rules are broken. For example when there is an offside (Abseits). Don’t ask what offside is! You only have to learn this special vocabulary if you love football. However, it is necessary to know how the words are formed, because the rules for this apply to every word.

The subjunctive / Der Konjunktiv

There are statements which express something real; these are statements in the indicative/Indikativ. And then there are statements which express a wish or a possibility or repeat something that others have said or you yourself said at an earlier time; these are statements in the subjunctive/Konjunktiv. The subjunctive expresses – something unreal, something only wished for, something only supposed – something said by you or others previously – reported/indirect speech The subjunctive often expresses a distance to the repeated statement of another person. There is a subjunctive I (Konjunktiv I) and a subjunctive II (Konjunktiv II).

The subjunctive II is the most frequently used form of the subjunctive; it is derived from the past tense, the preterite. The use is reduced to sein, haben, and the modal verbs. Owing to the difficulty in the use of the subjunctive II, all other verbs are generally rephrased with würde, especially in the spoken language. The subjunctive is also often avoided altogether in the spoken language and replaced by the indicative, if the statement can be easily misunderstood. For example:
